conclusion: Laser beam moves from point A to point C on the flat face of the semi-cylindrical brick.
Each point along AC acts as a source of a ray that refracts at the curved interface.
A ray launched at an interior angle θ will exit the semicylinder only if Snell’s law permits: sin θ ≤ 1/n.
The last ray that emerges corresponds to the critical condition sin θ = 1/n, where θ = θc = arcsin(1/n).
The ray meets the curved surface at a point for which line-of-sight geometry gives AO = r cos θc.
The vertical distance the spot must travel along AC before the ray ceases to emerge is Δy = r – r cos θc = r (1 – cos θc).
At a constant speed v, the required time is t = Δy / v.
Final answer: t = [ r (1 – cos( arccos(√(1 – 1/n²)) )) ] / v which simplifies to t = r [1 – √(1 – 1/n²)] / v.
